structured_info.title_en: PLEXE: A Platooning Extension for Veins
structured_info.abstract: Cooperative driving in general and Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC) or platooning in particular require blending control theory, communications and networking, as well as mechanics and physics. Given the lack of an integrated modeling framework and theory as well as the prohibitively high costs of using prototypes for what-if studies, simulation remains the fundamental instrument to evaluate entire cooperative driving systems. This work presents PLEXE, an Open Source extension to Veins that offers researchers a simulation environment able to run experiments in realistic scenarios, taking into account physics and mechanics of the vehicles, communications and networking impairments, and Inter-Vehicle Communication (IVC) protocol stacks. PLEXE is easily extensible and already implements protocols to support platooning and cooperative driving applications and several state of the art cruise control models. We describe the structure of the simulator and the control algorithms that PLEXE implements and provide two use cases which show the potential of our framework as a powerful research tool for cooperative driving systems.
structured_info.methodology: The paper presents PLEXE, an extension to the Veins simulation framework, integrating SUMO for mobility simulation and OMNeT++ for network simulation. It includes car-following models, controller algorithms (CC, ACC, CACC), and platooning maneuvers.
structured_info.conclusion: PLEXE provides a versatile, open-source simulation framework for platooning research, enabling realistic studies of vehicle dynamics, communication networks, and control algorithms. It supports mixed traffic scenarios and is extensible for future research.

analysis.Overview: The paper introduces PLEXE, an open-source extension to the Veins simulator for studying platooning and cooperative driving systems. It integrates vehicle dynamics, communication networks, and control algorithms.
Background_and_Motivation: The research addresses the challenge of developing efficient, safe, and automated cooperative driving systems.
The motivation is to provide a realistic simulation tool for platooning research, overcoming the limitations of existing simulators.
The authors highlight the lack of integrated tools and the high cost of prototype testing, emphasizing the need for a comprehensive simulation framework.
The problem is linked to broader challenges in vehicular networking, control theory, and traffic efficiency.
The paper contributes to vehicular networking, control systems, and transportation engineering.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts include platooning, CACC, and IVC.
The logical relationship involves using IVC to enhance vehicle coordination, enabling CACC for platooning.
Key assumptions include realistic vehicle dynamics, communication impairments, and mixed traffic scenarios.
The paper contributes a practical tool for the research community, enabling reproducible and extensible studies.
Methodology: PLEXE extends Veins, integrating SUMO for mobility and OMNeT++ for network simulation. It includes car-following models and control algorithms.
The methodology is novel in its integration of vehicle dynamics, communication, and control, providing a realistic and extensible framework.
Data sources include simulated vehicle trajectories and network conditions. Preprocessing involves configuring control algorithms and communication protocols.
Experimental design includes use cases for controller analysis and join maneuvers, with metrics like string stability and convergence time.
The research follows a systems engineering paradigm, combining control theory and networking.
Results: Key results demonstrate the string stability of different controllers (ACC, CACC) and the effectiveness of join maneuvers.
Results are significant for platooning research, showing reliable performance under realistic conditions.
Argumentation_and_Logic: The argument structure starts with the need for integrated simulation, presents PLEXE's design, and validates it with use cases.
Key steps include problem identification, simulator design, implementation, and validation.
Strengths include the comprehensive integration of components. Weaknesses include the lack of real-world validation.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths: Open-source, extensible, realistic simulation of mixed traffic.
Limitations: Assumes ideal sensor performance and does not address all real-world communication challenges.
The choice of simulation paradigm limits conclusions to simulated environments.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: The paper positions PLEXE as a community tool for platooning research.
Terminology includes technical terms like string stability and CACC. The tone is technical and collaborative.
Citations establish authority by referencing prior work in control theory and vehicular networking.
Conclusions_and_Implications: PLEXE is a valuable tool for platooning research, enabling large-scale and reproducible studies.
Future work includes real-world validation and extending the framework for more complex scenarios.
